"Unclean" captures the cultic nuance better than "common."

**"Snare" (v. 13)**: The *skandalon* was originally the trigger-stick of a trap. It refers to something that doesn't just make one trip, but causes a total downfall or entrapment.

**"Right-standing" (v. 17)**: *Dikaiosynē* is often translated "righteousness," but in the context of the Kingdom of God and the Roman community, it refers to the state of being in right relationship—both with God and with the community.

**"Conviction" (v. 22, 23)**: The Greek *pistis* is usually translated "faith." However, in this specific ethical context regarding food and days, it refers to the personal assurance or "trusting-conviction" that a particular action is acceptable to God. To act against this conviction is "sin" because it is a violation of one's integrity before God.

verses.text: Now we who are strong have an obligation to shoulder the weaknesses of those who lack strength, rather than simply living to please ourselves.
Each of us should please our neighbor for their good, to build them up.
For even the Messiah did not live to please himself; rather, as it is written: *The insults of those who insulted you have fallen upon me.*
For whatever was written in the past was written for our instruction, so that through endurance and through the encouragement found in the Scriptures, we might hold onto hope.
May the God of endurance and encouragement grant you to think in harmony with one another, in accordance with Christ Jesus,
so that with one passion and one voice you may glorify the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Therefore, welcome one another into your fellowship, just as the Messiah welcomed you, for the glory of God.
For I tell you that Christ has become a servant to the circumcised on behalf of God’s truthfulness, in order to confirm the promises made to the patriarchs,
and so that the nations might glorify God for his mercy. As it is written: *Because of this, I will acknowledge you among the nations and sing praises to your name.*
And again it says: *Rejoice, O nations, along with his people.*
And again: *Praise the Lord, all you nations, and let all the peoples extol him.*
And again, Isaiah says: *The Root of Jesse will appear, the one who rises to rule the nations; in him the nations will place their hope.*
Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace as you trust in him, so that you may overflow with hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
I myself am convinced about you, my brothers and sisters, that you are indeed full of goodness, filled with all necessary knowledge, and capable of instructing one another.
Yet I have written to you quite boldly on some points, as if to remind you again, because of the grace given to me by God

to be a cultic minister of Christ Jesus to the nations. I perform the priestly service of the good news of God, so that the offering of the nations may be acceptable, having been sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
Therefore, in Christ Jesus, I have reason to boast regarding my service to God.
For I will not dare to speak of anything except what Christ has accomplished through me to bring the nations to obedience, by word and deed,
by the power of signs and wonders, and by the power of the Spirit. As a result, from Jerusalem and all the way around to Illyricum, I have fulfilled the proclamation of the good news of the Messiah.
In this way, I make it my point of honor to preach the good news not where Christ has already been named, so that I do not build on someone else’s foundation.
But as it is written: *Those who were told nothing about him will see, and those who have not heard will understand.*
This is why I have been prevented so many times from coming to you.
But now, since I no longer have a place for work in these regions, and since I have had a longing to come to you for many years,
whenever I travel to Spain, I hope to see you as I pass through and to be sent on my way there by you, once I have first enjoyed your company for a little while.
At the moment, however, I am traveling to Jerusalem to serve the holy ones.
For Macedonia and Achaia were pleased to make a contribution for the poor among the holy ones in Jerusalem.
They were pleased to do it, and indeed they are indebted to them. For if the nations have shared in their spiritual blessings, they are obligated to serve them in material things.
So when I have completed this and have safely delivered this fruit to them, I will set out for Spain by way of you.
And I know that when I come to you, I will come in the full measure of the blessing of Christ.
Now I urge you, brothers and sisters, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to join me in my struggle by praying to God on my behalf.
Pray that I may be rescued from those in Judea who refuse to believe, and that my service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the holy ones there,
so that by God’s will I may come to you with joy and find rest in your company.
May the God of peace be with all of you. Amen.

chapters.notes:
**"Shoulder the weaknesses" (v. 1)**: The Greek *bastazein* means to lift, carry, or endure a burden. Paul is not just suggesting tolerance but active support of the "scrupulous" or "powerless" (*adynatōn*).

**"Build them up" (v. 2)**: *Oikodomēn* refers to the metaphor of "edification" as constructing a building. In Paul’s context, this is the communal strengthening of the church "house."

**"The Messiah" (v. 3, 7, 8)**: While *Christos* is often treated as a proper name, in these contexts Paul is emphasizing Jesus’s fulfillment of the Davidic and covenantal roles (referencing Ps 69, the promises to the patriarchs, and the "Root of Jesse").

**"One passion and one voice" (v. 6)**: The Greek *homothymadon* suggests a shared impulse or inner heat/passion, while *en eni stomati* (with one mouth) refers to the outward liturgical expression of that unity.

**"Welcome one another" (v. 7)**: *Proslambanesthe* means to take someone to yourself, often into your home or circle of intimacy. Given the tensions between "weak" and "strong" (Jewish and Gentile Christians), this is a call to full table-fellowship.

**"Cultic minister... priestly service... offering" (v. 16)**: Paul uses a dense cluster of sacrificial and temple language (*leitourgon*, *hierourgounta*, *prosphora*). He envisions his missionary work as a priestly ritual where the converted Gentiles themselves are the sacrifice being presented to God.

**"Point of honor" (v. 20)**: *Philotimoumenon* literally means "loving honor." Paul views the pioneering of the gospel in unreached areas as a matter of holy ambition and dignity.

**"The holy ones" (v. 25, 26, 31)**: Traditionally "saints" (*hagiois*). In the first century, this designated the members of the Messianic community as God’s "set-apart" people, echoing the status of Israel.

**"Safely delivered this fruit" (v. 28)**: *Sphragisamenos* means "to seal." In a commercial context, it refers to sealing a shipment to guarantee its contents and ownership. Paul is acting as the guarantor that the collection from the Gentiles reaches the Jerusalem poor intact.

**"Join me in my struggle" (v. 30)**: *Synagōnisasthai* is a vigorous term related to athletic or combat struggle (*agōn*). Paul views prayer not as a passive wish but as an active, taxing partnership in his dangerous mission.

verses.text: I introduce to you our sister Phoebe, who is a deacon of the church in Cenchreae.
Welcome her in the Lord in a manner worthy of God's holy people, and assist her in whatever matter she may require from you. For she herself has been a patron to many, including me.
Give my greetings to Prisca and Aquila, my coworkers in Christ Jesus.
They risked their own necks for my life; I am not the only one who is grateful to them, but also all the churches of the nations.
Greet also the church that meets in their home. Greet my dear friend Epaenetus, who was the first harvest for Christ in the province of Asia.
Greet Mary, who has worked very hard for you.
Greet Andronicus and Junia, my fellow Jews and my fellow prisoners; they are prominent among the apostles, and they were in Christ even before I was.
Greet Ampliatus, my dear friend in the Lord.
Greet Urbanus, our coworker in Christ, and my dear Stachys.
Greet Apelles, who has been tested and approved in Christ. Greet those who belong to the household of Aristobulus.
Greet Herodion, my fellow Jew. Greet those in the household of Narcissus who are in the Lord.
Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, women who labor in the Lord. Greet my dear Persis, who has labored hard in the Lord.
Greet Rufus, a choice man in the Lord, and his mother—who has been a mother to me as well.
Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brothers and sisters with them.
Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the holy people with them.
Greet one another with a holy kiss. All the churches of Christ send their greetings to you.
Now I urge you, brothers and sisters, to keep a watchful eye on those who cause divisions and create obstacles that go against the teaching you learned; turn away from them.
For such people are not enslaved to our Lord Christ, but to their own physical appetites. Through their smooth talk and flattering speech, they deceive the hearts of the guileless.
The report of your obedience has reached everyone, so I rejoice over you. But I want you to be wise regarding what is good, and innocent regarding what is evil.
The God of peace will soon crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus be with you.
Timothy, my coworker, sends greetings to you, as do Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my fellow Jews.
I, Tertius, who penned this letter, greet you in the Lord.
Gaius, who has hosted me and the whole church, sends his greetings. Erastus, the city treasurer, and our brother Quartus greet you.

chapters.notes:
**"Deacon" (v. 1)**: The Greek *diakonos* is used here with a specific church (Cenchreae), suggesting Phoebe held a recognized office or position of service. Translating this as "servant" in the general sense often obscures the official nature of her role in the early church.

**"Patron" (v. 2)**: The Greek *prostatis* refers to a legal and social protector or benefactor. In the Roman world, a patron provided financial support, legal standing, and social resources to those under their care. Phoebe was not merely a "helper"; she was a woman of means and influence who supported the movement.

**"First harvest" (v. 5)**: The Greek *aparchē* (literally "firstfruit") refers to the first portion of a harvest dedicated to God. In the context of missions, it denotes the first convert in a specific region, signifying the promise of a greater harvest to follow.

**"Prominent among the apostles" (v. 7)**: The phrase *episēmoi en tois apostolois* most naturally signifies that Andronicus and Junia are themselves considered apostles (in the wider sense of commissioned messengers) who are highly regarded. "Junia" is a female name; the historical attempts to read this as a masculine name ("Junias") lack manuscript evidence from the first millennium.

**"Fellow Jews" (v. 7, 11, 21)**: The Greek *syngenēs* can mean "relative" or "kinsman," but Paul consistently uses it in Romans (cf. 9:3) to refer to his "kin according to the flesh"—his fellow Jewish compatriots.

**"Physical appetites" (v. 18)**: Literally "their own belly" (*koilia*). In the context of Greco-Roman moral philosophy and Pauline thought, this refers to being governed by base instincts and self-interest rather than by the Spirit or the Lord.

**"Guileless" (v. 18)**: The Greek *akakos* describes people who are innocent or unsuspecting—those who do not have evil in themselves and therefore do not easily suspect it in others.

**"Penned this letter" (v. 22)**: Tertius was the *amanuensis* (scribe) who physically wrote the text as Paul dictated it. His insertion of a personal greeting reflects the collaborative nature of the letter's production.

**Verse 24**: This verse (a repetition of the grace found in v. 20) is omitted as it is absent from the most reliable and earliest Greek manuscripts (such as P46, Sinaiticus, and Vaticanus). It was likely added by later scribes to provide a formal liturgical conclusion.
